translated: Cultivating the Profound Meaning of the Flower Ornament, the Contemplation of Returning the Source When Delusion Ends
Composed by Dharma Master Fazang of the Great Canon Translation Monastery during the Tang Dynasty
The complete teaching is difficult to fathom, yet it is suddenly manifested by peering at a single dust mote; the perfect principle is unfathomable, yet the slightest hair is seen to fully reveal it.
However, when function is based on essence, there is a tendency of distinctions;
when phenomena rely on principle to manifest, they naturally have the form of a single moment.
It is just like when illness arises, medicine is employed; when delusion is born, wisdom is established.
If the illness and delusion are false, then the medicine is false; an empty fist is raised to stop crying.
If the mind is unobstructed, then the Dharma is unobstructed; empty space is used to illustrate its pervasiveness.
Once awakened and enlightened, what obstructions and unobstructions are there?

The hundred negations cease their clinging, and the four propositions are cut off from increase and decrease. Therefore, medicine and illness are both obliterated, and stillness and disturbance are both merged. By dissolving the grasper and the grasped, one enters the profound principle, obliterating nature and characteristics and returning to the Dharma realm.

I secretly see that the profound principles are vast and the wondrous meaning is rare and subtle. Those who look at it rarely investigate its source, and those who seek it rarely exhaust its limits. Therefore, true emptiness is obstructed at the forefront of the mind, always becoming the field of conditions and thoughts;
The actual reality resides in front of the eyes, but it turns into the realm of names and characteristics.
Now, it comprehensively includes the profound and mysterious, and encompasses the great principles. It brings out sutra scrolls in the dust, and turns the wheel of Dharma in the hairs.
The enlightened one, their virtue will flourish on that very day;
The ignorant one, their hope will be cut off in many lifetimes;
Those who understand the meaning, for them, even mountains and rivers can be easily moved;
Those who go against the principle, for them, even a small amount is difficult to enter.

I will immediately review the past edicts and examine the old chapters, fully equipped with the profound texts of the three treasuries, relying on the wondrous meaning of the five vehicles. Redundant words must be eliminated, and missing meanings restored.

Although it is newly compiled without doubt, moreover, the previous guidelines have a basis. Exhausting this nature ocean and gathering the forest of practices, separately raising six gates, all becoming one contemplation, interpenetrating without confusion, the one moment is bright and clear. Hoping to return to the deluded direction, the feelings are the same as the bright sun. The gentlemen who uphold the Way will look down and examine it.
Now briefly clarifying this contemplation, it is generally divided into six gates:
First, listing the names;
Later, extensively distinguishing.
First, revealing the one essence, referring to the essence of self-nature purity and perfect brightness.
Second, giving rise to two functions:
First, the function of the ocean seal and the constant abiding of myriad phenomena;
Second, the function of the perfect brightness and freedom of the Dharma realm.
Third, demonstrating three pervasiveness:
First, the pervasiveness of a single dust mote pervading the Dharma realm;
Second, the pervasiveness of a single dust mote giving rise to the inexhaustible;
Third, the pervasiveness of a single dust mote containing emptiness and existence.
Fourth, practicing four virtues:
First, the virtue of the wondrous function of following conditions without bounds;
Second, the virtue of abiding in dignified conduct;
Third, the virtue of nurturing life through gentleness and sincerity;
Fourth, the virtue of universally taking on the suffering of sentient beings.
Fifth, entering the five cessations:
First, the cessation of illuminating phenomena as empty and detached from conditions;
Second, the cessation of contemplating people as tranquil and cutting off desires;
Third, the cessation of the arising of nature as flourishing and natural;
Fourth, the cessation of the manifestation of concentration light as being without thought;
Fifth, the cessation of the profound interpenetration of phenomena and principles as being non-dualistic.
Sixth, giving rise to the six contemplations:
First, the contemplation of returning phenomena to mind as true emptiness;
Second, the contemplation of the wondrous existence of phenomena manifesting from mind;
Third, the contemplation of the perfect interfusion of the secrecy of mind and phenomena;
Fourth, the contemplation of the manifestation of the wisdom body in various conditions;
Fifth, the contemplation of many bodies entering one realm image;
Sixth, the contemplation of the mutual manifestation of host and guest as a net of Indra.
First, revealing the one essence refers to the essence of self-nature purity and perfect brightness.

However, this is precisely the essence of the Dharma-nature within the TathÄgatagarbha, which from the very beginning is innately replete. Abiding in defilement, it is not defiled; cultivated and purified, it is not pure. Therefore, it is called intrinsically pure.
The essence of nature universally illuminates without any obscurity. Therefore, it is called perfect and bright.

Moreover, it follows the flow and is defiled without being stained; it reverses the flow and removes defilement without being purified. It can also abide in the holy body without increase and in the ordinary body without decrease.
Although there are distinctions between concealment and manifestation, there is no difference in the disparity.
When covered by afflictions, it is concealed; when realized by wisdom, it is manifested.
It is not produced by the cause of birth, but only realized by the cause of realization.
The Awakening of Faith says:

The essence of suchness has the meaning of great wisdom and light, the meaning of universally illuminating the Dharma realm, the meaning of true and real cognition, and the meaning of the intrinsically pure mind.
It is explained extensively in that text. Therefore, it is called the intrinsically pure and perfect and bright essence.
As for the arising of the two functions based on the essence below, it means that based on the previous pure essence, two functions arise.
First, the function of the constantly abiding myriad phenomena of the ocean seal.
As for the ocean seal, it is the fundamentally enlightened true suchness.

When delusion ends and the mind is clear, the myriad phenomena are all manifested, just like when the ocean causes waves to arise due to the wind. If the wind stops and the ocean water becomes clear, no phenomena are not manifested.
The Awakening of Faith says:
The treasury of immeasurable merit and virtue, the ocean of the true suchness of the Dharma-nature.
This is why it is called the samÄdhi of the ocean seal.
The sÅ«tra says:
The myriad phenomena and myriad images are sealed by a single dharma.

As for the single dharma, it refers to the one mind. This mind encompasses all mundane and supramundane dharmas, which is the essence of the great general characteristics of the dharma gate of the one dharma realm. It only has distinctions due to deluded thoughts. If one leaves deluded thoughts, there is only true suchness. Therefore, it is called the samÄdhi of the ocean seal.
The Huayan Sutra says:

Sometimes manifesting the forms of boys and girls, devas, dragons, asuras, and mahoragas, according to their preferences, all causing them to see, the forms and appearances of sentient beings are each different, and their karmic actions and sounds are also immeasurable, in this way they are all able to manifest, by the majestic power of the SamÄdhi of the Ocean Seal.
Based on this meaning, it is called the SamÄdhi of the Ocean Seal.

Second, the free function of the perfect illumination of the Dharma realm is the Huayan SamÄdhi, which means extensively cultivating myriad practices to accord with principle and perfect virtue, pervading the Dharma realm to realize bodhi.
As for Huayan, the flower has the function of bearing fruit, and practice has the ability to produce results.
Now it relies on events to symbolize, and therefore uses the flower as a metaphor.

As for adornment, when practice results in the perfection of fruition, it accords with principle and is true, with both nature and characteristics gone, and both subject and object completely severed, manifesting brilliantly, and therefore it is called adornment.
It is precisely because the practices of those not of the true lineage cannot accord with the truth, how could there be practices that adorn the truth that do not arise from the truth?

This means that the truth pervades the end of delusion, and there is no practice that is not cultivated. Delusion penetrates the source of truth, and there is no appearance that is not quiescent. Therefore, it is called the perfect and bright self-mastery of the Dharma realm.
The Huayan Sutra says:

Adorning and purifying inconceivable lands, making offerings to all Tathagatas, emitting great light without limit, liberating sentient beings also without limit, giving, morality, patience, vigor, and meditation, wisdom, skillful means, and supernormal powers, all of these are self-mastery, by the power of the samadhi of the Buddha's adornment.
Based on this meaning, it is called the samadhi of the Buddha's adornment.
Third, demonstrating the three pervasivenesses means that based on the previous two uses, each use universally pervades the Dharma realm, therefore it is called pervasiveness.
As for the three pervasivenesses:
First, a single dust mote universally pervades the Dharma realm.
It means that objects have no inherent nature, and are formed by embracing the true nature. Since the true nature is boundless, objects also follow suit.
The sutra says:
In each dust mote of the Flower Treasury world, the Dharma realm is seen. Jewel lights manifest Buddhas like gathering clouds. This is the Tathagata's mastery of his realm.
Based on this meaning, one should know that a single dust mote pervades the Dharma realm.
Second, a single dust mote gives rise to the boundless and pervasive.

It means that dust has no self-nature, and when it arises, it must rely on the true nature. Since true suchness is endowed with merits as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, the functions that arise based on the true nature are also myriad.
The Awakening of Faith says:

As for true suchness, its essence has the meanings of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. Because it is pure and unchanging, and has the meaning of self-mastery, it is endowed with merits as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, and even more, up to the meaning of having nothing lacking.
The sutra says:

In this ocean of the Flower Treasury world, whether it be mountains, rivers, or even trees, dust, hair, and so forth, each and every one is none other than the true suchness of the Dharma realm, endowed with boundless virtues.

Based on this meaning, one should know that a single dust mote is principle and phenomena, person and Dharma, that and this, support and supported, defilement and purity, cause and effect, same and different, one and many, vast and narrow, sentient and insentient, and the three bodies are the ten bodies.
Why is this?

Because principle and phenomena are unobstructed, phenomena and phenomena are unobstructed, the Dharma is like this, and the ten bodies freely transform each other, it is only the realm of universal vision.
Among the above phenomena, each one again mutually contains and includes each other, each possessing a realm of inexhaustible layers upon layers.
The sutra says:
The boundless ocean of all Dharma gates, all converge within a single Dharma site. The Buddha has spoken of the nature of dharmas like this, and the eye of wisdom can illuminate this skillful means.
Question:
According to what you have said, then on a single dust mote, principle is not concealed, phenomena are not merged, texts are not left uninterpreted, and meanings are not left unexplained.
Now, how should those who study and practice understand and realize the sudden resolution of myriad doubts at the point of dust?
Moreover, on a single dust mote, what is defiled?
What is called pure?
What is true?
What is called conventional?
What is called birth and death?
What is called nirvana?
What is called afflictions?
What is called bodhi?
What is called the Dharma of the Lesser Vehicle?
What is called the Dharma of the Great Vehicle?
Please explain and resolve this, so that I may hear what I have not heard!
Answer:

The great wisdom is perfectly clear, seeing the subtle dust mote and pervading the ocean of nature, the true source is brightly manifested, dwelling in a single dust mote and illuminating the entire body.
The myriad dharmas arise simultaneously in the single moment, the principle is without before and after.
Why is this so?
Because this single dust mote of illusory characteristics can obscure the true, it is defilement.
Because this dust mote characteristic is empty and nonexistent, it is purity.
Because the inherent essence of this dust mote is the same as suchness, it is the true.
Because this dust mote characteristic is conditionally arisen and illusory, it is the conventional.
Because the dust mote characteristic changes moment by moment, it is birth and death.
Because observing the arising and ceasing of the dust mote characteristic is exhausted and empty, without reality, it is nirvÄá¹‡a.
Because the size of the dust mote characteristic is all the deluded mind's discrimination, it is afflictions.
Because the inherent essence of the dust mote characteristic is originally empty and tranquil, and conceptualization naturally ends, it is bodhi.
Because the inherent essence of the dust mote characteristic is devoid of the imagined, it is the HÄ«nayÄna teaching.
Because the nature of the dust is unborn and unceasing, it appears as if dependent on others, which is precisely the Mahayana Dharma.

Thus, this is a brief explanation. If explained in detail, suppose all sentient beings harbor different doubts and ask the TathÄgata simultaneously with a single dust-mote word, the TathÄgata would explain it with a single dust-mote word. One should contemplate this deeply.
The sÅ«tra says:
The boundless ocean of all Dharma gates is completely explained with a single word, leaving nothing out.
Based on this meaning, it is called the inexhaustible pervasiveness arising from a single dust-mote.
Third, a single dust-mote contains the pervasiveness of emptiness and existence.
It means that the dust has no self-nature, which is emptiness, and its illusory appearance is still present, which is existence.

It is precisely because illusory form has no substance that it must not be different from emptiness, and true emptiness possesses merits that penetrate through existence.ğŸ”½Contemplating form as emptiness, one achieves great wisdom and does not dwell in saá¹ƒsÄra;
Contemplating emptiness as form, one achieves great compassion and does not dwell in nirvÄá¹‡a;
Because form and emptiness are non-dual, compassion and wisdom are not different, only then is it truly real.
The MahÄyÄna-Å›raddhotpÄda-Å›Ästra says:
Before the path, bodhisattvas have three doubts regarding this wondrous existence of true emptiness:ğŸ”½First, they doubt that emptiness destroys form, and grasp at the emptiness of annihilation.
Second, they doubt that emptiness is different from form, and grasp at emptiness outside of form.
Third, they doubt that emptiness is a thing, and grasp at emptiness as having existence.
The commentary now says, Form is illusory form, which must not obstruct emptiness. Emptiness is true emptiness, which must not obstruct form.
If it obstructs form, it is the emptiness of annihilation. If it obstructs emptiness, form is real.
Just as a single dust mote already possesses the above wondrous existence of true emptiness, you should know that each and every dust mote is also like this.

If one realizes this principle, then one can contain the ten directions within a particle without deficiency, and encompass the nine times in a thought, with the long and short simultaneous. Therefore, one attains the subtle and supreme words that manifest the perfect teaching in the slightest, and the extraordinary holy assembly that appears in its entirety in a single dust mote. It completely transcends the limits of verbalization and conceptualization, and penetrates beyond the realm of metaphors and analogies.
The sutra says:
There is a great sutra scroll, its size equal to the three thousand worlds, contained within a single dust mote, and so it is with all dust motes.
There is an intelligent person with pure eyes who clearly sees this, breaks open the dust mote and takes out the sutra scroll, widely benefiting sentient beings.

If one speaks from the perspective of principle, then the sentient beings in the dust mote mistakenly conceive the sutra scroll to be the great wisdom of perfect clarity. Since the essence of wisdom is boundless, it is said to be the size equal to the three thousand worlds.
Based on this meaning, it is called a single dust mote containing emptiness and existence everywhere.
Below this, based on this all-pervading realm, one practices the four virtues. That is to say, based on the one dust that is able to pervade, one cultivates the four kinds of virtuous practices.
First, the virtue of the marvelous function of following conditions without bounds.
It means relying on the true to give rise to function and widely benefit the multitude of beings.

Sentient beings' faculties are not equal, their understanding and acceptance differ in myriad ways, and their desires are not the same. Responding to their capacities and bestowing the Dharma, giving medicine according to the illness, enabling them to take and practice it. The VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra fully clarifies this meaning.
Moreover, because of great compassion, it is called following conditions;
because of great wisdom, it is called marvelous function.
Moreover, it greatly destroys provisional names while always liberating sentient beings.

Therefore, it is said to follow conditions. Understanding that the nature of sentient beings is empty, there is truly no one to liberate is called marvelous function.ğŸ”½Moreover, because principle is identical to phenomena, it is called following conditions; because phenomena are identical to principle, it is called marvelous function.
Moreover, because the true does not contradict the conventional, it is called following conditions; because the conventional does not contradict the true, it is called marvelous function.
Moreover, it is based on the origin giving rise to the branches, following conditions, and gathering the branches back to the origin, thus the wondrous function.

It is because the Dharma has no divisions, and arising must be simultaneous. The truth of reality does not obstruct myriad differences, and the manifestation of response is none other than a single moment. In function, it surges like waves and boils like a cauldron, fully utilizing the true essence to operate and move;
In essence, it is like a mirror's clarity and water's calmness, raising the following of conditions to meet quiescence.
If it is like the light radiating colors, it is without mind yet illuminates the ten directions;
It is like a clear mirror reflecting forms, without movement yet presenting myriad images.
Therefore, it is said to be the virtue of the wondrous function following conditions without direction.
Second, the virtue of the existence of abiding in deportment.
It refers to the four deportments of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down.

The eighty thousand for the Great Vehicle and the three thousand for the Lesser Vehicle are the models for abiding and upholding, straightening out the disordered sequence of the six harmonies, the ladder leading out of the three realms, the swift ship crossing the sea of suffering. Saving beings and guiding the deluded, none is greater than this.

However, the golden countenance has hidden its radiance, and the true teachings have declined and become corrupted. Teachers transmit their own views, causing the teachings to lack a framework and be confused. They indiscriminately draw from the pure stream, indiscriminately mixing gains and losses, and falsely intermingling with true purity. Therefore, beginners encounter things and create offenses. Not relying on the sÅ«tras and vinaya, they confuse ordinary people's thoughts, sinking themselves and others. This is very lamentable.
Therefore, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra says:
Neither greatly sinking nor slightly floating, always abiding in right mindfulness, purifying pure conduct.
The Huayan Sutra says:
Precepts are the basis of unsurpassed enlightenment. One should fully uphold pure precepts.
The Fanwang Sutra says:
By this, the multitude of dust-like bodhisattvas attain perfect enlightenment.
The Awakening of Faith says:

Because one knows that the essence of the Dharma-nature is without violation of precepts, therefore, in accordance with the Dharma-nature, one practices the perfection of morality, namely, not killing, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not speaking falsely, and staying far away from greed, hatred, deceit, flattery, and wrong views. One should also stay away from busyness, have few desires, be content, and even be greatly afraid of small offenses. One should not take lightly the precepts established by the TathÄgata, and always protect against slander and suspicion so as to prevent sentient beings from falsely committing offenses.
Use this deportment to uphold and transform sentient beings.
Question:

According to what was said above, true suchness is of one characteristic, the Buddha's essence is non-dual, and is endowed with all merits, then why is it necessary to have the precepts of deportment and so forth?
Answer:
It is like a great maá¹‡i jewel, whose nature is bright and pure, but for a long time has been covered with dust and has coarse defilements.
If a person only thinks of the nature of the jewel but does not polish it in various ways, it will never become pure.
The essence of suchness is empty and pure, but for a long time it has been tainted by the defilements of ignorance and afflictions.
If a person only contemplates suchness and does not cultivate it through various means such as upholding precepts, concentration, and wisdom, it will never become pure.
Based on this meaning, it is necessary to uphold the precepts.
Question:
The five groups of renunciant monastics transcend worldly life and can maintain dignified conduct.
How can those in the householder's life, whose bodies are entangled in worldly affairs, avoid offenses?
Answer:
Those who have left the household life have their own strict rules, while those in the householder's life generally uphold the five precepts.

The three refuges and five precepts are indeed the ferry and bridge to cross the ocean of suffering, the foundation for entering nirvana, the gradual steps for creating the Vinaya, and the lofty foundation for the seven groups of Buddhist followers. All good deeds arise from this, and it is truly the level ground of the Buddha's teachings.
The sutra says:
If one's precepts are impure, samadhi will not manifest.
You should know that precepts are the essence of concentration, and wisdom is the function of concentration. When the three learnings are complete, one realizes enlightenment.
The Four Part Vinaya says:
First, upholding the precepts without violation, the bhiká¹£u's demeanor is dignified, even his enemies cannot approach him, if he does not act according to the Dharma he will be reprimanded.
Based on this principle, it is said that there is virtue in abiding with dignified conduct.
Third, the virtue of nurturing beings through gentleness and sincerity.
It means that great wisdom illuminates truth and is called sincerity, and great compassion saves beings and is called gentleness;
Moreover, sincerity is about the original nature being unchanging,

and gentleness is about following the flow without being stuck. Gentleness means subduing and extinguishing afflictions, and gentleness means practicing in accordance with principle. Using this method of harmony, to nurture sentient beings.

Moreover, being honest means that one's essence is free from deceit, and one's speech and actions are consistent. One accumulates virtue in one's mind and is not constrained by fame and profit, regarding gold as if it were a lump of dirt, and cherishing the teachings as more precious than a jewel. One only engages in right action to guide beings, quickly wishing for oneself and others to be fulfilled. Therefore, it is said that the virtue of guiding beings is to be gentle and honest.
Fourth, the virtue of universally taking on the suffering of sentient beings.

It means that in cultivating all practices, one does not do so for one's own sake, but only wishes to widely benefit all beings, with enemies and friends regarded equally. Universally causing them to abandon evil and fully cultivate myriad practices, quickly realizing enlightenment.

Moreover, the bodhisattva's great compassion and great vows take the body as collateral, and in the three evil destinies, they redeem all suffering sentient beings, wishing to cause them to attain happiness, to the end of future kalpas, with a mind free from discouragement, not hoping for even a hair's worth of gratitude from sentient beings.
The Flower Ornament Sutra states:

The vast cloud of great compassion pervades everywhere, and the immeasurable giving of one's body is equal to the dust motes in the Buddha-lands. By the power of practicing for many eons in the past, this world now has no defilements.
It is said that sentient beings' false grasping and moment-to-moment change is called suffering;
Bodhisattvas teach them to understand that the aggregates are empty and quiescent, with a nature that has never existed, and therefore it is said to be free from suffering.
Question:
Sentient beings are boundless, and their suffering and karma are boundless. How can Bodhisattvas universally replace sentient beings in experiencing suffering?
Answer:

As for Bodhisattvas replacing sentient beings in experiencing suffering, it is due to the power of great compassion and skillful means. It is only because sentient beings falsely grasp and do not understand that the essence of karma arises from delusion, and there is no way to escape suffering.

Bodhisattvas teach them to cultivate the two approaches of calming and contemplation, with the mind not wavering for a moment. Cause and effect are lost, and suffering and karma have no way to arise. It is only by preventing them from entering the three evil paths that it is called the virtue of universally replacing sentient beings in experiencing suffering.
The Abhidharma-samuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ says:
In the perception of the firm in the unfirm, deeply abiding in the inverted, free from the afflictions and their troubles, attaining the supreme enlightenment.
The above clarifies the four kinds of virtues of practice.
From here on, it subsumes the functioning and returns to the essence, entering the five gates of stillness.

The five gates of stillness refer to relying on the previously able practice of the four virtues, the characteristics immediately empty, the characteristics exhausted, the mind clear, and cultivating stillness.
What is said to be entering is the nature and characteristics both obliterated, the essence pervading the Dharma realm, entering without the characteristics of entering, which is called entering.
The Flower Ornament Sutra says:
The profound realm of the TathÄgata, its measure equal to space, all sentient beings enter it, yet in reality there is nothing to enter.
Moreover, according to the Sutra on Entering the Buddha's Realm, it says:
Entering the samÄdhi of all signlessness, seeing all dharmas as quiescent.
Always entering equality, therefore respectfully bowing without observing anything.
This means that all sentient beings are originally not outside the realm of the TathÄgata, and there is nothing more to enter.
It is like a person who, due to delusion, takes east to be west;
But when they awaken, they realize that west is east, and there is no separate east to enter.
Sentient beings, due to delusion, think that delusion can be abandoned and that truth can be entered;
But when they awaken, they realize that delusion is itself truth, and there is no separate truth to enter.
This principle is the same. It is not entering that is entering, so it is called entering.
Why is it so?
Because entering and not entering are originally equal, the same Dharma realm.
The Awakening of Faith says:
If there are sentient beings who can contemplate non-thought, this is called entering the gate of suchness.
As for the five cessations:
First, the cessation of illuminating phenomena as empty and detached from conditions.

It means that the nature of the truth of ultimate reality is originally empty and tranquil, and the phenomena of the truth of conventional reality appear to exist but are empty. The truth of ultimate and conventional reality is clear and empty, utterly without basis. The wisdom that is able to cognize is tranquil, and the objects that are cognized are empty. Mind and objects are not constrained, and the essence merges into the vast expanse. At the time of right realization, causes and conditions are both absent.
The VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra says:
The Dharma does not belong to causes, nor does it reside in conditions.
Based on this meaning, it is called the samÄdhi of illuminating the Dharma's clear emptiness and being free from conditions.
Second, the samÄdhi of contemplating the person's tranquil fearlessness and cutting off desires.

It means that the five aggregates have no owner, which is called tranquil fearlessness. Empty quiescence without seeking is called cutting off desires. Therefore, it is called the samÄdhi of contemplating the person's tranquil fearlessness and cutting off desires.
Third, the samÄdhi of the nature giving rise to profuse flourishing and being so of itself.

It means that relying on the essence to give rise to function is called the nature giving rise. Giving rise to responding to myriad differences is called profuse flourishing. Being so from ancient to present is called being so of itself.

It means that the principle of suchness, as it is, accords with conditions, and myriad dharmas arise together. As it is, it returns to the nature, and therefore it is called the principle of the arising of the nature.
The sÅ«tra says:
From the unmoving root, all dharmas are established.
This is the meaning.
Fourth, the samÄdhi of the manifestation of the light of non-thought.

As for the light of samÄdhi, it refers to the white pure jeweled net and the wheel-turning king's jewel in the teaching of the One Vehicle. It is said that the essence of this jewel is clear and penetrating, illuminating the ten directions equally, accomplishing things without thought, and all thoughts come from it;
Although it manifests wondrous functions, the mind has no thoughts.
The Huayan Sutra says:
It is like a wheel-turning king who accomplishes the seven precious things. The place where they come from cannot be found. The nature of karma is also like this.

If there are sentient beings who enter this gate of great stillness and wondrous contemplation, without thought or deliberation, they naturally accomplish things, like that precious pearl which illuminates equally far and near, clearly manifesting and penetrating the void, not obstructed by the dust, mist, or clouds of the two vehicles and non-Buddhists, therefore it is called the stillness of radiant appearance without thought.
Fifth, the stillness of the non-appearance of the profound interpenetration of phenomena and principle.
It means that the phenomena of illusory appearances and the principle of no nature mutually conceal and reveal, therefore it is called profound interpenetration.

Moreover, because principle is manifested through cultivation, phenomena penetrate principle, and practice arises from principle, principle penetrates phenomena, mutually existing and mutually negating, therefore it is called profound interpenetration.
Profound interpenetration means that great wisdom alone exists, its essence pervades the Dharma realm, and great compassion saves beings with myriad practices.

Compassion and wisdom are both fused, nature and characteristics are both extinguished, therefore it is called the stillness of the non-appearance of the profound interpenetration of phenomena and principle.
The above clarifies the five stillnesses.
From here on, it relies on stillness to give rise to contemplation.
Question:
According to the above principles and meanings, relying on them to practice is sufficient for perfection. Why is it still necessary to enter the two gates of calming and contemplation?
Answer:
The Awakening of Faith says:
If one cultivates calming, it counteracts the ordinary person's attachment to the mundane world and can abandon the narrow views of the two vehicles.
If one cultivates contemplation, it counteracts the narrow faults of the two vehicles not giving rise to great compassion and far removes the ordinary person's not cultivating wholesome roots.
For this reason, the two gates of calming and contemplation mutually assist each other and are inseparable.
If one does not cultivate calming and contemplation, there is no way to enter the path of enlightenment.
The Flower Ornament Sutra says:
It is like a garuá¸a flapping its two wings and stirring up the ocean waters, causing them to part in two so that it can observe the nÄga-kings whose lifespans are about to end and seize them.

The TathÄgata's appearance in the world is also like this. Using the two wings of great stillness and wondrous observation, he stirs the great ocean of love of sentient beings, causing it to split in two, observing sentient beings whose faculties are mature, and liberating them.
Based on this meaning, one must cultivate stillness and observation.
Question:
Since the two gates of stillness and observation are the essential points, beginners who have not yet understood how to settle the mind should be shown the correct path to return to.
Answer:
According to the Awakening of Faith, it says:

'If one cultivates stillness, dwell in a quiet place, sit upright with right intention, do not rely on breath, do not rely on physical appearance, do not rely on space, do not rely on earth, water, fire, or wind, and do not rely on seeing, hearing, cognition, or knowing. As for the six contemplations, the first is the contemplation of the true emptiness of subsuming phenomena within the mind.
It means that all dharmas in the three realms are created by the one mind alone. Apart from the mind, there is not a single dharma that can be obtained. Therefore, it is said to return to the mind.
It means that all discriminations are only due to one's own mind. There has never been an external object that can serve as a condition for the mind.
Why is it so?
Because the mind does not arise, external objects are originally empty.
The treatise says:
Because it is based on consciousness only, and objects have no inherent nature, the meaning of true emptiness is established;
Because objects do not exist, the fundamental consciousness does not arise.
The sutra also says:
Before realizing that objects are only mind, various discriminations arise. Once realizing that objects are only mind, discriminations do not arise.
Knowing that all dharmas are only mind, one abandons the characteristics of external objects. Because of this, discriminations cease, and one awakens to the equality of true emptiness.
Just as there is a great physician in the world who uses wonderful medicine to cure illnesses, the buddhas are also like this, teaching beings about the only mind.
By this one knows that the mind manifests objects, and objects manifest the mind. The mind does not reach objects, and objects do not enter the mind.
One should contemplate in this way. Wisdom is very profound. Therefore, it is called the contemplation of returning objects to the mind and the true emptiness of phenomena.
Second, the contemplation of the wondrous existence of manifesting objects from the mind.
It means that phenomena are not obstructed by principles, and differences are formed according to phenomena.

It means that in the previous approach, phenomena are returned to the essence. In this approach, one relies on the essence to give rise to functions and cultivates myriad practices to adorn the reward land.
Moreover, in the previous approach, phenomena are returned to the essence, revealing the Dharma body.

In this approach, relying on the essence to give rise to functions, one cultivates to form the reward body. Therefore, it is called the contemplation of manifesting objects from the mind and the wondrous existence of phenomena.
Third, the contemplation of the secret and perfect interfusion of mind and objects.
As for mind, it refers to the unobstructed mind. Buddhas realize it to form the Dharma body.
As for objects, it refers to unobstructed objects. Buddhas realize it to form the Pure Land.

Within this approach, it is divided into four statements, as explained in the commentary on the Profound Discourse.

Now this [contemplation] simultaneously integrates and unifies the mind and the objective realm, thus it is called the secret and perfectly integrated contemplation of the mind and the objective realm.
Fourth, the contemplation of the reflection of wisdom appearing in various conditions.

It means that the essence of wisdom is only one, able to reflect on various conditions. The characteristics of conditions are originally empty, and the essence of wisdom illuminates quiescence. When all the characteristics of conditions are exhausted, suchness alone remains.

It means that all conditioned dharmas without exception contain true nature, just as the sun shines and appears in the vast sky. Those with eyes all see it, and even the blind are benefited by it, knowing the seasons and the periods of cold and heat, and the insentient grasses and trees all grow.

Sixth, the mutual manifestation of the host and its retinue, the net of Indra.

This means taking oneself as the host and others as the retinue, or taking a single dharma as the host and all dharmas as the retinue, or taking a single body as the host and all bodies as the retinue. Whichever single dharma is brought up, the host and its retinue are simultaneously included, with layers upon layers being inexhaustible. This illustrates how the Dharma-nature manifests in layers, with all phenomena being inexhaustible, and it is also the inexhaustible layers of compassion and wisdom.
